CLUE: Ancient goddess found in the ace
OUTPUT: ['Demeter - Goddess of harvest, agriculture, and fertility in Greek mythology.', 'Isis - Ancient Egyptian deity associated with fertility, motherhood, and death.', 'Ceres - Roman goddess equivalent to the Greek goddess Demeter.', 'Cybele - Mother Goddess of Phrygia and later Rome, often linked with nature and fertility.', 'Parvati (Shakti) - Hindu goddess representing motherhood and fertility.', 'Amalthea - The goat-nymph in Greek mythology who nurtured the infant Zeus.', 'Rhea - Titaness of birth, harvest, and regeneration in Greek mythology, sister to Cronus (Kronos).', 'Gaia - Ancient Greek primordran goddess representing Earth as a fertility deity.', "Mazu - Chinese folk religion's goddess associated with protection, particularly of seafarers and fishermen.", 'Tailanga - Mother Goddess in Hindu mythology symbolizing motherhood and earthly wealth.', 'Asherah (Ishartot) - Ancient Canaanite fertility goddess worshiped by the Israelites as well.', 'Ninhursag - Mesopotamian sky goddess of the earth, representing abundance and fecundity.', 'Eir - Norse deity associated with healing and protection in childbirth.', 'Athena Parthenos - A statue of the Greek goddess Athena (not a direct ancient fertility figure but revered as the mother goddess), though not strictly an embodiment of fertility.', 'Hathor - Ancient Egyptian goddess associated with love, beauty, music, and maternal care.', 'Isis-Osiris Complex - A combination in Egyptian mythology symbolizing aspects of motherhood (Isis) and resurrection/fertility (Osiris).', "Vesta - Roman goddess of the hearth, home, family, and chastity but indirectly related to ancient fertility through her association with the family unit's well-being.", 'The Moirai (Fates) - Greek mythology figures who control destiny; while not directly linked to fertility, they influence life cycles that include birth.', 'Artemis - Ancient Greek goddess associated with hunting and wilderness but also had a connection to childbirth as a protective mother figure.', 'Gaia (Terra) - Latin for Earth, the primordial deity representing earth and fertility in Roman mythology.']
